# Joint Pain Framework and Septic Arthritis Emergency
## Top-down triage
```
Joint pain
├── Monoarthritis
│   ├── Septic arthritis (emergency)
│   ├── Crystal arthropathy (gout/CPPD)
│   └── Trauma/hemarthrosis
├── Polyarthritis
│   ├── Mechanical (OA)
│   ├── Inflammatory systemic disease (RA, SpA, vasculitis)
│   └── Other mimics
└── Synovial fluid interpretation
```

## Synovial fluid WBC orientation
| Category | Synovial WBC trend |
| --- | --- |
| Normal | <200 |
| Non-inflammatory | 200-2,000 |
| Inflammatory | 2,000-50,000 |
| Septic concern | often >50,000 with neutrophil predominance |

## Septic arthritis must-not-miss
- Red/hot/swollen joint with severe pain on passive motion is emergency.
- Arthrocentesis is essential for diagnosis and source characterization.
- Prompt empiric IV antibiotics + joint drainage/washout are standard urgent steps.
- Delays can rapidly destroy cartilage.

## Pediatric septic hip pearl
- Kocher-style criteria increase probability for septic arthritis.
- If unclear, hip imaging/aspiration pathway is used to separate septic arthritis from transient synovitis.

# Fight Bite, Disseminated Gonococcal Infection, OA, and Seronegative Back Pain
## Fight bite (clenched-fist injury)
- Small MCP laceration after punch-to-mouth can seed deep structures with oral polymicrobial flora.
- Do not primarily close a contaminated fight-bite wound.
- Management: irrigation/debridement + amoxicillin-clavulanate class coverage.

## Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI)
- Two patterns: purulent monoarthritis or triad of migratory polyarthralgia + tenosynovitis + dermatitis.
- Joint cultures may be negative; NAAT from mucosal sites is key.
- Treatment: ceftriaxone-based regimen plus chlamydia co-treatment when indicated.

## Osteoarthritis update
- Mechanical pain pattern: worse with use, brief morning stiffness.
- Typical hand distribution: DIP/PIP changes; MCP sparing is a clue against RA.
- If MCP hook osteophytes pattern is present, evaluate iron-overload arthropathy context.

## OA management ladder
1. weight loss + strengthening exercise,
2. topical NSAID,
3. oral analgesic strategies,
4. arthroplasty for end-stage functional loss.

## Seronegative spondyloarthropathy core
- Inflammatory back pain improves with activity and worsens with rest.
- Ankylosing spondylitis: sacroiliitis progression, extra-articular uveitis risk.
- Reactive arthritis: post-GU/GI trigger pattern with mucocutaneous/systemic signs.

# HSP, Cryoglobulinemia, TMJ Dysfunction, and Joint Pain Rapid Recap
## IgA vasculitis (HSP)
- Typical pediatric pattern: palpable purpura (lower body), arthralgia/arthritis, abdominal pain, renal involvement.
- GI complications (including intussusception) and urinalysis findings guide monitoring.

## Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis
- Strong association with hepatitis C.
- Typical profile includes palpable purpura, weakness, arthralgias, low complement (especially C4).

## TMJ dysfunction
- Jaw pain/clicking with chewing, often linked to bruxism/stress.
- Initial treatment is conservative: soft diet, night guard, NSAID-centered symptom control.

## Rapid recap table
| Condition | Key clue | Next step |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Septic arthritis | hot monoarthritis + severe movement pain | urgent arthrocentesis + IV antibiotics + drainage |
| Gout | acute crystal inflammatory attack (often podagra) | crystal confirmation + anti-inflammatory therapy |
| OA | mechanical pain with short morning stiffness | staged conservative-to-surgical management |
| Fight bite | MCP wound after punch injury | no primary closure; debridement + oral-flora coverage |
| DGI | tenosynovitis-dermatitis-migratory pain or purulent arthritis | NAAT-based confirmation + ceftriaxone regimen |
| Ankylosing spondylitis | inflammatory back pain in younger patient | sacroiliac-focused evaluation and anti-inflammatory/biologic pathway |
| HSP | palpable purpura + abdominal/renal signs in child | supportive care + renal/GI monitoring |

# Systemic Autoimmune Disorders Part 1: RA-SLE-MCTD Framework
## Classification map
```
Systemic autoimmune disease
├── Joint-predominant erosive disease: Rheumatoid arthritis
├── Multi-organ immune-complex disease: SLE
├── Overlap phenotype: MCTD (anti-U1-RNP)
└── Thrombotic obstetric autoimmunity: APS
```

## Pattern-recognition principle
- Diagnosis depends on joint distribution, stiffness pattern, organ involvement, and antibody profile rather than isolated arthralgia.

## RA core
- Symmetric inflammatory small-joint synovitis (MCP/PIP/wrist) with prolonged morning stiffness.
- DIP sparing favors RA over OA hand pattern.
- Anti-CCP is highly specific; ESR/CRP track activity.

## RA high-risk complications
| Complication domain | Example | Clinical consequence |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Cervical spine | C1-C2 instability | cord compression risk during airway manipulation |
| Lung | interstitial disease | progressive dyspnea and functional decline |
| Eye | scleritis/uveitis context | vision-threatening inflammation |
| Vascular | accelerated atherosclerosis | increased MI/stroke risk |

## RA treatment logic
- Methotrexate-centered DMARD strategy with folate supplementation and toxicity surveillance.
- Screen for latent TB/hepatitis before biologics.

# Felty Syndrome and SLE Core Diagnostics
## Felty syndrome
- Long-standing erosive RA + splenomegaly + neutropenia.
- Recurrent infection risk rises with severe neutropenia.

## SLE profile
- Young-woman predominant multisystem disease with fatigue, photosensitive rash, serositis, migratory non-erosive arthritis, renal/CNS risk.
- Malar rash classically spares nasolabial folds.

## Lupus nephritis
- Major prognostic determinant.
- Abnormal urinalysis/proteinuria/active sediment should trigger renal biopsy for class-based treatment decisions.

## Antibody/complement map
| Marker | Clinical use |
| --- | --- |
| ANA | sensitive screen |
| anti-dsDNA | higher specificity; activity correlation (especially renal activity) |
| anti-Smith | high specificity |
| C3/C4 | low in active immune-complex consumption states |

## Pregnancy differentiation pearl
- Distinguish lupus flare from preeclampsia using inflammatory urine findings/complement context and full maternal-fetal assessment.

# Drug-Induced Lupus, APS, and MCTD
## Drug-induced lupus
- Typical culprits include hydralazine/procainamide/isoniazid patterns.
- Anti-histone positivity is classic.
- Major renal/CNS lupus manifestations are less typical; stop culprit drug first.

## Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS)
- Clinical requirement: thrombosis and/or characteristic pregnancy morbidity.
- Lab requirement: persistent positivity (repeat at least 12 weeks apart) among lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, anti-beta2-glycoprotein I.
- PTT can be prolonged despite prothrombotic in-vivo behavior.

## APS treatment by setting
| Clinical setting | Preferred anticoagulation strategy |
| --- | --- |
| Non-pregnant | warfarin-based long-term therapy |
| Pregnancy | LMWH + low-dose aspirin |

## MCTD
- Overlap clinical phenotype spanning lupus/scleroderma/myositis features.
- High-titer anti-U1-RNP is the key marker.
- Raynaud and puffy hands are frequent pattern clues.

# Rapid Recap: Autoimmune Disorders Part 1 and Transition
## Treatment/monitoring table
| Disease context | Key therapy | High-yield caution |
| --- | --- | --- |
| RA | methotrexate-first DMARD axis | folate support; liver/marrow/lung toxicity surveillance |
| SLE baseline | hydroxychloroquine | retinal monitoring for long-term use |
| Lupus nephritis | class-directed immunosuppression | renal biopsy before regimen selection |
| Drug-induced lupus | remove offending drug | anti-histone pattern helps confirmation |
| APS in pregnancy | LMWH + aspirin | avoid warfarin in pregnancy |

## Scenario anchors
1. Anti-histone with culprit drug exposure -> drug-induced lupus.
2. Puffy hands + Raynaud + overlap features -> evaluate anti-U1-RNP for MCTD.
3. Pregnant hypertensive proteinuric patient with low complement/inflammatory urine -> lupus flare branch remains critical differential.
4. Longstanding RA with UMN signs/cervical concern -> evaluate atlantoaxial instability urgently.
5. Longstanding RA + recurrent infections + splenomegaly -> check ANC for Felty syndrome.
6. New proteinuria in SLE -> renal biopsy pathway.

## Transition
- Next block focuses on seronegative spondyloarthropathies and connective-tissue fibrosis/dryness syndromes.

text:
# Seronegative Spondyloarthropathies and Connective Tissue Diseases Part 2
## Big-picture split
```
Part 2 autoimmune map
├── Seronegative spondyloarthropathies (RF-, often HLA-B27 linked)
│   ├── Ankylosing spondylitis
│   ├── Reactive arthritis
│   └── Psoriatic arthritis
└── Connective tissue disorders
    ├── Sjogren syndrome
    ├── Systemic sclerosis (limited vs diffuse)
    └── Raynaud phenomenon
```

## SpA comparison table
| Entity | Hallmark pattern | Core first-line approach |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Ankylosing spondylitis | inflammatory back pain + sacroiliitis | NSAID, then biologic escalation if refractory |
| Reactive arthritis | post-GU/GI trigger with ocular/urogenital features | NSAID-centered care, treat persistent trigger infection |
| Psoriatic arthritis | DIP disease, dactylitis, nail changes | phenotype-based anti-inflammatory/DMARD strategy |

## AS details
- Inflammatory back pain: improves with activity, worsens with rest/night.
- Sacroiliitis is core imaging target; MRI can detect earlier inflammatory change.
- Extra-articular risks: uveitis, aortic involvement, conduction abnormalities.

# Sjogren, Systemic Sclerosis, and Raynaud Management Pearls
## Sjogren syndrome
- Sicca syndrome: gritty dry eyes and xerostomia with swallowing difficulties.
- Often associated with anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB positivity.

## Diagnostic anchors
- Schirmer testing for tear production.
- Minor salivary gland (lip) biopsy supports diagnosis in selected uncertain cases.

## High-risk complication
- Increased risk of B-cell lymphoma (especially MALT-type patterns) with persistent glandular enlargement or systemic alarm signs.

## Systemic sclerosis framework
| Subtype | Typical antibody | Dominant organ risk |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Limited cutaneous (CREST pattern) | anti-centromere | pulmonary arterial hypertension/vascular phenotype |
| Diffuse cutaneous | anti-Scl-70 | interstitial lung disease and renal crisis risk |

## Scleroderma renal crisis (emergency)
- Sudden severe hypertension + AKI requires urgent ACE inhibitor strategy.
- Early creatinine rise does not preclude lifesaving ACE inhibition.

## Raynaud phenomenon
- Triphasic vasospastic color change (white-blue-red) with cold/stress.
- Evaluate for secondary autoimmune disease in severe/asymmetric or progressive presentations.

# Systemic Sclerosis and Raynaud Management Pearls
## Systemic sclerosis framework
- Disease process combines vasculopathy, immune activation, and progressive fibrosis.
- Limited cutaneous pattern (CREST, anti-centromere) vs diffuse pattern (anti-Scl-70 with higher visceral risk).

## Organ risk profile
| Subtype | Major risk emphasis |
| --- | --- |
| Limited | pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic vascular features |
| Diffuse | interstitial lung disease and renal crisis risk |

## Scleroderma renal crisis (emergency)
- Sudden severe hypertension + AKI requires urgent ACE inhibitor strategy.
- Early creatinine rise does not preclude lifesaving ACE inhibition.

## Raynaud phenomenon
- Triphasic vasospastic color change (white-blue-red) with cold/stress.
- Evaluate for secondary autoimmune disease in severe/asymmetric or progressive presentations.
